1. By September 2020, SALAC has received 1126 calls from law enforcement agencies and judiciary and provided LA on 652 secondary criminal cases in both Khatlon and Sughd oblasts of Tajikistan 2. 39 lawyers provide free primary legal aid in 34 districts and cities of Tajikistan (out of 68 e.g. half). SFLA was not expanded to Dushanbe city due to COVID-19 pandemic. 3.The law on Legal Aid was adopted by the Parliament of Tajikistan on July 7, 2020 4. State Agency Legal Aid Centre has been granted state budget resources to cover 20% of all its expenditures as planned initially. 5. Taking into account COVID-19 pandemic situation worldwide, the Project did not conduct planned Rule of Law Forum in 2020 that was postponed to 2021.

description.narrative: The Vietnam Provincial Governance and Public Administration Performance Index (PAPI)
capital of a political entity

sector.narrative: Eradicate poverty in all its forms and dimensions

description.narrative: 1) One time-series tool called 'the Viet Nam Provincial Governance and Public Administration Performance Index (PAPI)' established to measure local government performance in Viet Nam. PAPI is a rigorous policy tool that monitors and measures the performance of governance and public administration of all 63 provinces in Viet Nam based on citizens’ experiences. 2) Number of provinces responding to PAPI findings by seeking measures to improve their performance over time 3) Number of in-depth research conducted to bring insights into why public polices do not work and how to make them work better for the benefit of citizens 4) Number of provinces where annual PAPI surveys are conducted 5) Number of respondents per cycle of PAPI surveys

comment.narrative: Baselines (2017) are: 1) The Viet Nam Provincial Governance and Public Administration Performance Index (PAPI) 2016 published and disseminated at the national level, involving more than 600 participants from different government and non-government sectors. 2016 PAPI findings also disseminated through 15 diagnostic workshops in 15 different provinces to inform public officials, civil servants and elected representatives about their provincial performance from citizen perspective. PAPI data and findings also shared in different mainstream media channels to promote policy discussion with provinces during 2017. 2) 38 provinces (cumulatively since 2011) having responded to PAPI findings by introducing provincial directives or action plans to improve their performance. 3) 31 case studies (cumulatively since 2011) using PAPI data to look into the supply side’s inputs for dimensions under PAPI study completed.

1) The Viet Nam Provincial Governance and Public Administration Performance Index (PAPI) 2017 published and disseminated at the national level, involving more than 500 participants from different government and non-government sectors. 2017 PAPI findings also disseminated through 15 diagnostic workshops in 15 different provinces to inform public officials, civil servants and elected representatives about their provincial performance from citizen perspective. PAPI data and findings also shared in different mainstream media channels to promote policy discussion with provinces during 2018. 2) 40 provinces (cumulatively since 2011) having responded to PAPI findings by introducing provincial directives or action plans to improve their performance. 3) 34 case studies (cumulatively since 2011) using PAPI data to look into the supply side’s inputs for dimensions under PAPI study completed. 4) 2018 PAPI surveys conducted in all 63 provinces, ready for data analysis and reporting in 2019

PAPI data and findings also shared in different mainstream media channels to promote policy discussion with provinces during 2018. 2) 59 provinces (cumulatively since 2011) having responded to PAPI findings by introducing provincial directives or action plans to improve their performance. 3) 34 case studies (cumulatively since 2011) using PAPI data to look into the supply side’s inputs for dimensions under PAPI study completed. 4) 2018 PAPI surveys conducted in all 63 provinces 5) 14,304 citizens from all 63 provinces responded to 2018 PAPI surveys. By mid November 2018, national data was ready for analysis and reporting.

PAPI data and findings also shared in different mainstream media channels to promote policy discussion with provinces during 2020. 2) 63 provinces (cumulatively since 2011) having responded to PAPI findings by introducing provincial directives or action plans to improve their performance. 3) 38 case studies (cumulatively since 2011) using PAPI data to look into the supply side’s inputs for dimensions under PAPI study completed: due to COVID-19, activities under this result have been postponed to 2021. 4) 2020 PAPI surveys conducted in all 63 provinces, ready for data analysis and reporting from December 2020. 5) More than 15,500 citizens, including permanent residents and internal migrants, from all 63 provinces responded to 2020 PAPI surveys

description.narrative: Supporting national statistics systems and institutional frameworks to inform policy-making at macro and sectoral levels.
capital of a political entity

sector.narrative: Accelerate structural transformations

description.narrative: Number of policies reviewed, updated and aligned with Vision 2030, NTP2020 and SDGs

comment.narrative: Vision 2030 and NTP2020 published
A revised framework to deliver demand-driven technical support and timely capacity development interventions aligned with the National Statistical Development Strategy and the SDGs produced

A substantive revision of the Institutional Support to Statistics project was endorsed by the Project Board. The revised project provides a framework to deliver demand-driven technical support and timely capacity development interventions aligned with the National Statistical Development Strategy. It also addresses the statistical needs triggered by the context of COVID-19. Specifically, the technical support will be delivered under the following outputs: Output 1: GaStat capabilities to produce statistical data and information in light of the Kingdom's 2030 statistical vision strengthened. Output 2: GaStat capacities to integrate statistical analysis into decision-making processes enhanced with focus on achieving the SDGs and Saudi Arabia's Vision for 2030. Output 3: Modernization of the statistical systems enabled Output 4: Capacities for statistics governance and quality control strengthened Output 5: Nowcasting solution developed and preliminary early estimates of GDP and economic activity in KSA produced
Sources:
• The Project Revision Document inclusive of MYWP (2021 - 2024) • 2020 Project Board Meetings Minutes
Working on the agreed outputs is still ongoing.

A substantive revision of the Institutional Support to Statistics project was endorsed by the Project Board. The revised project provides a framework to deliver demand-driven technical support and timely capacity development interventions aligned with the National Statistical Development Strategy. It also addresses the statistical needs triggered by the context of COVID-19. Specifically, the technical support will be delivered under the following outputs: Output 1: GaStat capabilities to produce statistical data and information in light of the Kingdom's 2030 statistical vision strengthened. Output 2: GaStat capacities to integrate statistical analysis into decision-making processes enhanced with focus on achieving the SDGs and Saudi Arabia's Vision for 2030. Output 3: Modernization of the statistical systems enabled Output 4: Capacities for statistics governance and quality control strengthened Output 5: Nowcasting solution developed and preliminary early estimates of GDP and economic activity in KSA produced

Capacity developed to enhance the technical and statistical analysis machinery through provision of subject-matter experts on the core specialties; instituting benchmarks and best practices to guide performance excellence; extensive staff training and continuous learning.

The national census was planned for 2020. However, UNDP assisted in identifying gaps and challenges of national statistics to be addressed by the design of the census questionnaires (housing and establishments). This took consideration of the data requirements for SDGs and HDI.
A long-term statistician has been contracted under the project to review the integration between results of surveys within the General Authority for Statistics and external ones. He has also been tasked to develop the construction index and production prices index. Work is still in progress. Final results will be reflected by end of 2020. Knowledge transfer is planned within the expert's assignment to ensure that capacities of the Authority's personnel are well developed in the field of national accounts, indexes/indicators accounts and satellite account. Moreover, the Project Work Plan is undergoing a substantive revision to reflect emerging needs pertaining to the national census, and its relevant samplings as well as further alignment for the statistical development strategy with the SDGs.
Sources:
1. UNDP/ESCWA reporting on gaps of statistics. 2. The National Statistical Strategy towards 2030 (at https://www.stats.gov.sa/en/page/114)
Institutional framework for statistics reviewed and aligned with Saudi Vision 2030, NTP2020 and SDGs

This project between the UNDP and the General Authority of Statistics (GASTAT) aims to provide substantive and technical assistance to GASTAT. Capacity development was carried out regarding instituting benchmarks and best practices to provide excellent performance, extensive staff training and continuous learning. The project aims at upgrading information technology infrastructure because of the growing demand for indicators and reporting on sustainability at all sectors of the economy and establishing national databank to ease access to all national data.

description.narrative: - Mapping of management mechanisms, laws, regulations and policies, the health care model and types of health services offered, as well as the existing structures in the regions of the country - Mapping of work processes from top management in the MSPP to the health services involved in the health service network in urgencies and emergencies in the country - Identification of the epidemiological profile of the country - Definition of technical profiles for the work in management and assistance, in relation to the organizational structure and the definition of roles and technical areas for the development of policy and technical regulations - Number of processes mapped - Number of documents containing the profile of each service, its portfolio of services and clinical identity - Number of routine and best practices manuals, with standardized operational procedures - Number of clinical care protocols - Number of managers trained in issues of hospital management, enhancement of care processes related to urgent and emergency management, hospital pharmacies, health surveillance related to urgencies and emergencies, monitoring and evaluation, use of information systems and technologies; and maintenance of equipment - Number of reintegration and technical update workshops for the Health Center Community Workers - Number of study grants paid to community workers - Reforms completed - Number of pieces of equipment purchased - Number of people trained in the use of equipment - Plan for the Maintenance of Reference Community Hospitals - Sustainability Plan and Gradual Transfer of HCR and the IHR to MSPP management - % of implementation of the Plan for the Maintenance of Reference Community Hospitals and the Haitian Rehabilitation Institute (IHR). - % of project implemented - Team hired - Progress and monitoring reports

comment.narrative: - estruturar o centro cirúrgico de Jeremie, construção da garagem/área de desinfecção e aquisição de equipamentos e ambulâncias para o Centro de Ambulância Nacional; - iniciar as ações previstas nos componentes de urgência e emergência do Prodoc.

Under the output 1. Perform diagnostic assessment of the management model of urgency and emergency services in Haiti, the following activities were completed in 2017 and 2018:
1.1.Map the public health services that make up the urgency and emergency health services network in Haiti, at the community, reference community, and department levels. 1.2. Map work processes in the services involved that make up the in urgency and emergency health care network in Haiti. 1.3. Map the flow among the services that make up the urgency and emergency health care network in Haiti. 1.4. Identify the epidemiological profile of urgencies and emergencies in Haiti and the profile of references of the major treatment centers.
Activities foreseen in Output 2 - Provide technical support to the Ministry of Public Health and Population (MSPP) in defining the organizational structure, organizational chart, professional profile, and positions regarding the Management of Urgencies and Emergencies in the country” were conducted by GOH itself and will not be necessary under the scope of this Project anymore.
Outputs 3 and 4 were not initiated yet.
Outputs 5, 6 and 7 will be implemented through an Agreement with PAHO/WHO, signed in 2019.
Outputs 8, 9 and 10 are referred to the Agreement signed with UNOPS: 8. Support access to the provision of health care in urgencies and emergencies through the physical structuring of services and the technology park of the hospitals covered. 9. Support the operationalization on, and the follow-up of, the three HCRs (Bon Repos, Beudet and Carrefour) and the Haitian Rehabilitation Institute; 10. Transfer the total management of the HCRs and of the IHR to the MSPP.
In December 2018, the second Amendment to the Agreement with UNOPS was signed (Annex 1). Justification for that is that on June 2018, Doctors without Borders (Also known as MSF) announced it would shut down permanently two important hospitals in the Haitian capital that had been opened following the earthquake. The first to close was the 176-bed obstetrics hospital in the Delmas area of Port-au-Prince, which treated, without any charge, close to 500 patients a month and where more than 40,000 babies were born. The second, a 122-bed trauma hospital in Tabarre, which receives many cases of head trauma and fractures related to the use of motorcycles, is expected to close definitively in June 2019. Moreover, and in line with the MSPP main priority of reinforcing Emergency Care in the country, a decision to reinforce the Emergency Department (ED) of Port-au-Prince’s La Paix University Hospital (Hopital Universitaire de Lapaix – HUP) was imminent. MSPP requested the support of WHO/PAHO as well as the MOH to partake in a very strategic project which aims at renovating the current Emergency Department, rendering it an independent unit of the existing hospital, and upgrading its medical equipment and security infrastructure to be able to compensate and face the increasing pressure especially in Trauma and Emergency care.
Under the Outputs 8, 9 and 10, the following activities were initiated and/or completed by UNOPS in 2018:
• Inauguration of the chirurgical centers of the hospital Sant Antoine de Jeremie, which took place on January 15, 2018, in the presence of the Minister of Health of Haiti and the Minister of Health of Brazil. • Inauguration of the National Ambulances Center (CAN), which was held on March 23, 2018, in Port-Au-Prince, with the presence of the First Lady of Haiti, the Minister of Health of Haiti and the Minister of the Interior of Haiti. • Launch of a new protocol of wage payments for HCRs’s health personnel • Creation of a committee that will oversee the new constructions (COSTO) in the three (3) HCRs and the IHR (Haitian Rehabilitation Institute) that was created to support the Directorate for Health Services Organization and to facilitate the transition period at the end of Project. • Several missions were conducted by UNOPS to the HCRs for the installation of equipment, evaluation of the site and renovation of the emergency rooms, , capacitation in the use of new equipment, maintenance, etc. • Referring to the CAN, the following services were held: adaptation services in the meeting room, cafeteria and the warehouse; installation of the electrical and plumbing systems; training sessions on the safe use of biomedical equipment for the teams of nurses and first responders; training sessions dedicated to ambulance drivers; cleaning and disinfestation training for ambulances; maintenance services and repairs in ambulances damaged; assessments of ambulances from different parts of the country for the purpose of repairing these ambulances in the CAN garage. • UNOPS held several meetings during the year with the directors of the 3 HCRs, with the objective of presenting the proposal of the Transition Committee of Hospital Management to the MSPP.

description.narrative: Institutional capacities of VNMAC and MOLISA are strengthened to improve in the mine action activities and contaminated communities in Quang Binh and Binh Dinh are cleaner through UXO interventions
first-order administrative division
capital of a political entity
first-order administrative division

sector.narrative: Accelerate structural transformations

description.narrative: - VNMAC capacity to manage/coordinate sector; MOLISA capacity to oversee VA sector; project management capacity of both VNMAC and MOLISA - IMS managed by VNMAC; survivor tracking system managed by MOLISA - The development and usefulness of website managed by VNMAC personnel; resources mobilized for post-project follow-on activities - Number of ha expected for productive use following release - Number of MRE programmes/activities implemented. Number of MRE plans approved for application in other localities. - Number of survivors (disaggregated by gender and age-group) in QB and BD with enhanced mobility, earning income and/or engaging in other livelihoods and/or accessing vocational programs, and participating in PwD organizations.

comment.narrative: - Institutional capacity assessment of VNMAC and MOLISA has never been conducted - IM is currently undertaken in various locations in Vietnam without a unified system under VNMAC - Website (http://www.vnmac.gov.vn) exists but content is very limited for Vietnamese language part and almost empty for English part - Quang Binh and Binh Dinh’s requested plans for survey and clearance (specific data to be updated) - Only ad-hoc MRE interventions implemented in QB and BD - Only ad-hoc MRE interventions implemented in QB and BD

- Capacity building for mine action administration: o Development of a workplan and implementation of relevant recommendations from the capacity assessment within the timeframe and resource availability of VNMAC and possibly DSA. o Support on development of circulars on quality management, survey & clearance procedures/standards for Decree 18. - Survey & Clearance: o Survey of 2,240 ha. o Clearance of 5,140 ha. o Bentic electronic QMS fully operational, providing real-time update from the field for improved planning and informed decision-making. - Information management: o Information management system for KVMAP activities effectively managed by VNMAC; and revision of the KVMAP Information Management Regulations as per Decree 18 and Circular 195. o PwDs/UXO victim data system (about 75,000 individuals) managed by DSA/MOLISA and used for identification and provision of support to relevant target groups among the UXO victims. o KVMAP webpage managed by VNMAC and regularly updated. - Mine Risk Education: o MRE for schoolkids in 116 priority schools and 50 communes. o 75,000 children provided with MRE knowledge via formal and informal education activities. o 10,000 community people improved MRE awareness and knowledge via social media outreach. o 420 pupils creatively deliver MRE messages via televised game shows to attach attention from their peers and public. o MRE sustainable plan prepared and approved upon. - Victim Assistance: o UXO/mine victims receive necessary support, including health services, rehabilitation, livelihood, vocational support, etc. o 300 commune health workers, social workers, collaborators strengthen their skills of providing care and support for UXO/mine victims, including rehabilitation and support for livelihood planning and management.

- Capacity building for mine action administration: o Capacity development plan developed and shared with VNMAC for implementation. This includes supporting VNMAC’s continuing efforts in revision of the QCVN (Technical Regulations), Technical Survey SOP (TS SOP), and Quality Management SOP (QM SOP) following the Decree 18 and circular 195 on mine action. - Survey & Clearance: o Survey of more than 2,200 ha. o Clearance of more than 3,000 ha. o Bentic electronic QMS was finalized and handed over to VNMAC for implementation. - Information management: o Information management system for KVMAP activities effectively managed by VNMAC with more than surveyed 16,880 ha and cleared 6,600 ha uploaded on the system; o The KVMAP Information Management Regulations revised for review/comments in the provincial workshops. o PwDs/UXO victim data system managed by DSA/MOLISA and used for identification and provision of support to relevant target groups among the UXO victims. o More than 100 news on KVMAP activities uploaded into the KVMAP webpage. - Victim Assistance: o More than 4,100 UXO survivors in the two provinces received emergency support in response to the COVID-19. o 375 commune, district, and provincial officers were updated about legal documents and policies of supporting the vulnerable populations including UXO survivors and PwDs in response to COVID 19; and community-based rehabilitation skills.

• Completion of baseline study to identify baseline, annual targets, measuring indicators and means of verification, Detailed work plan for 2018-2020 with accordingly updated project schedule management, 2018-2020 Procurement plan, Project Handbook, and Communications plan • Completion of staff appointment/recruitment for JPMU • Survey and Clearance prioritization system, including decision-making criteria approved • Basic training for Survey and Clearance for 230 people from 73 survey/clearance teams completed • Advanced training on information management and quality management for 10 staff from VNMAC and 2 provincial IM units completed. • Pilot survey of 1000 ha concluded and clearance started. • MRE delivery strategy and action plan, incl. for survey and clearance sites, completed and approved; MRE activities started. • Victim Assistance (VA) baseline survey results and information management system for VA in Quang Binh and Binh Dinh completed. • VNMAC website and 2 provincial information units in Quang Binh and Binh Dinh established.

• Capacity assessment of VNMAC and DSA conducted and 40% of relevant recommendations implemented. • Information management: IM system for KVMAP activities established and managed by VNMAC; PwDs/UXO victims data system (about 80,000 cases) established and managed by DSA/MOLISA; VNMAC website upgraded and regularly updated with at least 200 news. • Survey & Clearance: Survey of 9,000 ha and Clearance of 1,800 ha • MRE events for the community people in 35 priority communes; MRE events for schoolkids in 35 priority schools; 30,000 children provided with MRE knowledge via formal and informal education activities; 3,000 community people improved MRE awareness and knowledge; 110 pupils creatively deliver MRE messages via televised game shows to attach attention from their peers and public. • Victim Assistance: 100 UXO/mine victims receive necessary support, including health services, rehabilitation, livelihood, vocational support, etc; 400 social workers, collaborators strengthen their skills of providing care and support for UXO/mine victims; Two social work centers enhanced capacity of providing support for PWDs and UXO/mine victims; A technical guideline from DSA on providing mine/UXO victims issued, which can be applicable for the other provinces throughout the country; Recommendations and comments from MA experts are integrated into the draft law of social work which is under development.

• Capacity assessment of VNMAC and DSA conducted and recommendations are being implemented. • Information management: IM system for KVMAP activities established and managed by VNMAC; PwDs/UXO victims data system (about 75,000 cases of PwDs and 9100 cases of UXO survivors) established and managed by DSA/MOLISA; VNMAC website upgraded and regularly updated • Survey & Clearance: Survey of 5396 ha and Clearance of 2316 ha • 2 trainings of trainers for 155 key teachers and district managers in Binh Dinh province. Then these trained teachers have facilitated 33 trainings of integration of EORE into curriculum for all school masters of all primary schools and teachers of subjects of “citizen education”, “nature and society”, and “science” at secondary schools throughout the province. After the training, EORE will be routinely integrated into the relevant subjects at different grades at primary and secondary schools. 4 two- day trainings for 175 community communicators who are key persons from Red cross, youth union, military command at communal and district levels were organized in Quang Binh and Binh Dinh provinces. After the trainings, the trained collaborators facilitated EORE awareness events in 50 targeted communes in the two provinces in the remaining of 2019. EORE educational video and audio clips have been continued to be broadcasted in Quang Binh and Binh Dinh from June 2019. The video clip produced for teaching school children about MRE has been posted on the website of the global Safe Ground campaign MRE events for the community people in 35 priority communes; MRE events for schoolkids in 35 priority schools; 30,000 children provided with MRE knowledge via formal and informal education activities; 3,000 community people improved MRE awareness and knowledge; 110 pupils creatively deliver MRE messages via televised game shows to attach attention from their peers and public. • Victim Assistance: Support services mapping completed.

1. 3 study visits conducted Study visit of representatives of Ministry of Finance of Montenegro to Slovakia in March 2019 with main objective to provide the technical assistance aimed at improving the public sector accounting and reporting systems. Study visit of Montenegrin representatives of municipalities and Ministry of Finance to Slovakia in October 2019 with the main purpose to get acquainted with the Slovak experiences so that the Ministry can prepare an adequate plan for public finance reform activities at the local level, to be implemented in parallel with the central level reforms. Study visit of Serbian representatives of 5 Serbian local self-governments and Standing Committee of Towns and municipalities took place on 14-17 May 2019. The focus of the of the study visit was on the examples of best Slovak practice in transforming the underdeveloped municipalities into locations attractive for both foreign and domestic investment. Experience shared by MF SR, Association of Towns and Communities of Slovakia, Slovak Union of Towns, mayors of Cifer and Malacky.
2. Based on information acquired, the MF SR will set up the budget support indicators and define the objectives of the requested TA project.

description.narrative: The main objective of the project is to strengthen the country's capacity to assess seismic risks, as well as to prevent and respond to potential earthquakes and associated cascading emergencies.
capital of a political entity

sector.narrative: Accelerate structural transformations

description.narrative: 1.1. Number of methodological recommendations and proposals for approbation of some modern methods of seismic microzoning and assessment of vulnerability of buildings 1.2 Number of developed seismic maps of different levels of zoning and directionality (updated) for the city of Ashgabat 1.3 Number of geospatial models of earthquake susceptibility to buildings in target areas (housing stock and administrative buildings) based on building and ground characteristics 2.1 Number of laboratories of the Institute of seismology equipped with necessary and updated scientific and technical equipment 2.2. Number of employees of scientific research institutes, ministries and departments that have passed trainings and courses on modern methods of seismic risk assessment 2.3 Number of scientific and methodological and practical bases developed to improve the principles of existing disaster preparedness, complex monitoring and reporting of seismic events 3.1 Number of developed scenarios for the emergencies and development of disasters in case of the impact of strong earthquakes in targeted settlements on an improved scientific and methodological basis, using the example of a spatially linked scenario for the development of consequences for different time intervals 3.2 Number of training methods and materials for assessing the risks of earthquakes, associated risks of secondary and cascade disasters replicated and sent to local executive bodies for further use 3.3. Number of recommendations to the Ministry of Education on the inclusion of modules to assess seismic hazard and risk in the educational process of pilot universities for the further involvement of junior personnel in scientific activities. 3.4 Number of investment strategies for DRR at the macro level

comment.narrative: 1.Last version of seismic microzoning of Ashgabat city (scale 1:25000) was approved in 2001. 2.Until now, the Institute of seismology was not dealing with issues of seismic risk assessment 3.? Relations with international organizations on the matter of seismic risk assessment are limited: the Institute of seismology, as well as the relevant Office of the Ministry of Defense, are not sufficiently involved in international practice.

1.1. The number of methods in various disciplines to fulfil the targets for the project – 3. 1.2. The number of types of practical work in various disciplines aimed at obtaining new information geological-geophysical, engineering-geological nature, as well as systematic data on the technical condition of buildings and structures - 2. 1.3. The number of updated maps tectonic and seismological direction for the city of Ashgabat - 2. 1.4. A number of studies and regional assessments of seismic vulnerability of buildings are representative of categories - 1. 2.1. The number of laboratories of the Institute of seismology and atmospheric physics, Academy of Sciences of Turkmenistan, equipped with modern scientific and technical equipment - 3. 2.2. The number of employees of scientific research institutes, ministries and departments, held training courses on modern approaches and techniques in the field of seismic risk - 20. 2.3. The number of scientific-methodological AIDS for training of personnel of research institutes at national level - 2.

1.1. A critical analysis of modern techniques is performed: a) mapping of active tectonic faults; b) seismic micro-zoning; C) seismic risk assessment. Based on the analysis, methodological recommendations for their use were prepared. 1.2. 4 stages of certification of buildings in Ashgabat were completed with the preparation of a single passport. Due to the long delay in financing the project, the 5th stage of certification, as well as preparatory geological and geophysical work to determine the velocities of transverse waves and complex measurements and observations to obtain data on the resonant frequency characteristics of soils, were postponed to 2021. 1.3. For the same reason, the mapping of active tectonic faults and the seismic micro-zoning map has been postponed to 2021. 1.4. Due to the long delay in financing the project, work has been partially carried out to determine the seismic vulnerability of each of the representative categories of buildings in Ashgabat. The work will continue and should be completed in 2021. 2.1. Modern equipment is supplied for 3 laboratories of the Institute of seismology and atmospheric physics of the Academy of Sciences of Turkmenistan. 2.2. In connection with the situation caused by the COVID-19 the conduct of training course on the assessment of vulnerability of buildings is also postponed to 2021 2.3. All documents were prepared, a competition was held and a national Consultant was selected to compile a Russian-Turkmen and English-Turkmen explanatory dictionary on Geology, Geophysics, seismology, seismic hazard, seismic vulnerability and seismic risk. But due to lack of funding, the contract with the National Consultant was not concluded.

1.1. Number of methodological recommendations and proposals for approbation of some modern methods of seismic microzoning and assessment of vulnerability of buildings - 2 1.2 Number of developed seismic maps of different levels of zoning and directionality (updated) for the city of Ashgabat - 2 2.1 Number of laboratories of the Institute of seismology equipped with necessary and updated scientific and technical equipment - 2 2.2. Number of employees of scientific research institutes, ministries and departments that have passed trainings and courses on modern methods of seismic risk assessment - 30 psns

1.1. Conducted analysis of existing seismic zoning maps (general, detailed, microzoning). The process of certification of buildings and assessment of their vulnerability was started and will continue in 2020. 1.2. The process of developing seismic maps is slightly delayed due to the long process of receiving data from Ministry of Defense. The process started at the end 2019 and will continue in 2020. 2.1. Part of the necessary technical equipment was procured and delivered for Institute of seismology. Procurement of more technical equipment was contracted and will be delivered early 2020. 2.2. Three trainings were conducted (including introductory and advanced courses) on teaching geographical information systems (GIS) and their application. 25 employees of scientific research institutes, ministries and departments attended the training.
Due to different objective reasons, project started its operations around September 2018 and most of the targeted results will be achieved in 2019 and subsequent years of the project

1.1 There is the quantity of procedures of a various area of expertise for performance of target tasks under the project. -3 1.2 There is the quantity of types of practical works of the various area of expertise, directed to receiving of a new information of geological-geophysical, engineering-geological character, as well as the systematized data about a technical condition of buildings and constructions. - 2 1.3 There is the quantity of the updated maps of a tectonic and seismological orientation for the territory of Ashgabat city. - 2 1.4 There is the quantity of researches and territorial assessments of seismic vulnerability of buildings of representative categories. - 1 2.1 There is the quantity of laboratories in the Institute of seismology and physics of the atmosphere of the Academy of science of Turkmenistan, were equipped by the modern scientific and technical equipment. - 3 2.2 There is the number of employees of scientific research institutes, the ministries and the authorities which have been trained under modern approaches and procedures in the field of seismic risk. – 20 2.3 There is the quantity of scientifically-methodical manuals for training personnel of scientific research institutes at a national level. - 2

comment.narrative:
No cross-sector strategy for low emission development LEDS and NDC action and investment programme.
Several gaps have been identified in the current MRV system as part of work to produce the 3rd communications. Lack of records and poor record keeping systems at company level has also contributed to data gaps.
Limited public, private investments and public-private-academic expertise in low emission development. direct investments and other capital inflows. This has contributed to a piecemeal mitigation response. No renewable Energy policy

Energy Efficiency Policy completed and implementation start 6. Solar thermal bankable proposal developed and fundraising is launched 7. The IDBZ Climate Change facility is fully set up and operationalized and fundraising launched

2018 TARGET: Initial stakeholder engagement for policy and legislative review and priority instruments for review are identified Internal consultations were held among the various Gvt Departments to identify Laws and Policies to be reviewed under this project. 6 instruments including the Wildlife Act were identified.
2018 TARGET - Consultations and strategy for establishing Multi-Agency Wildlife Crime Units in place fight IWT and forest crime Internal consultations were conducted to introduce the concept of Multi-Agency Wildlife Crime Prevention Units
2018 TARGET: Needs assessment and training plan for key law enforcement agents This target was not achieved due to conflicting engagements with the law enforcement agencies
2018 TARGET: Comprehensive strategy and plan to support each of the 4 CAMPFIRE Wildlife Conservancies (CWCs) developed Draft TORs were developed and approved by the PSC for UNDP to proceed with the recruitment of a consultant to develop a comprehensive strategy and plan to support each of the 4 CWCs.
2018 TARGET: Mechanism for small grants facility for the area developed and agreed (including priority ideas for CBWM, SFM, CC, SLM and CWC support for the area); Draft TORs were developed and approved by the PSC for UNDP to proceed with the recruitment of a consultant to conduct the survey to identify priority livelihood options across the landscape
2018 TARGET: Project Website This was deferred as the Knowledge Manager recruitment was only concluded in December 2018.

PROJECT MANAGEMENT SUPPORT
2019 TARGET: 3 Project Board and Technical Committees meetings

2019 Target: - Review at least two of the following acts and policies; Parks and Wildlife Act; Wildlife Policy; and the development of Human Wildlife Conflict Policy, Communal Land Forest Produce Act and the Forest Act.
Workshops to identify gaps in the Parks and Wildlife Act, Forest Act and Communal Land Forest Produce Act were conducted. The following were identified as key gaps in the Parks and Wildlife Act: -o There is no clear offence on possession of cyanide o There is need to harmonize Acts. Absence of harmonized legislation (EMA, Forestry, Zimbabwe Parks) on hazardous substances Gaps that exists in the forest legislations (Forest Act and Communal Land Forest Produce Act). The following were identified: - o The two pieces of legislation lack Sustainable Forest Management principles. o Commercialization of forest produce should be included in the Act. Communities need to realize value of the forests for them to be effectively involved in the management of the forests. o Devolution in the management of the resource - communities should be actively involved in the management of the forests. Currently the state controls management of forests with little to no power by the communities, who are the resource users. ZPWMA started consultation processes on wildlife policy. A number of key stakeholders in the wildlife sector were consulted. Consultative Workshops for the development of the Human and Wildlife Conflict Policy were held with key stakeholders being consulted.
2019 Target: - Facilitate transboundary dialogue process between Zimbabwe, Zambia and Mozambique and finalise drafting of the Lower Zambezi-Mana Pools TFCA MoU and ZIMOZA Agreement.
A meeting to finalise the ZIMOZA and Lower Zambezi Mana Pools TFCA Agreements was held. During the meeting inputs from Mozambique, Zambia and Zimbabwe were incorporated into the agreements and revised copies were to be sent to partner countries for review and confirmation.
2019 Target: - Resuscitation of 40 Environmental Sub Committees (ESC), 3 Environmental Committees in Hurungwe, Mbire and Muzarabani Districts. 70 Environmental Sub-Committees (ESCs) in the three districts were resuscitated. 3 Environmental committees were established in the three districts
2019 Target: - Support establishment of 3 nurseries and drilling of 10 boreholes in 3 CWCs. Procurement process was completed.
2019 Target: - Initiation of at least 3 livelihoods enhancement activities through the Small Grants mechanism 2 NGOs signed grant agreements with UNDP to implement livelihoods activities in the 3 districts
2019 TARGET: Participate in GWP meetings and national meetings for knowledge exchange including tourism and wildlife economy-related meetings The project supported some project staff and community representatives to attend the African Wildlife Economy Summit held in Victoria Falls. The Summit provided a platform for exchange of lessons and experiences between the Zambezi Valley Biodiversity Project and other conservation programmes in Africa on community participation and beneficiation in the African Wildlife Economy
2019 TARGET: Project Board and Technical Committees meetings 3 Project technical committee meeting were conducted and 2 board meetings.

Outcome 1. Increased national capacity for IWT control, and integrated wildlife and woodland management 2020 Target: - Conclude at least 2 drafts of the following acts and policies; Parks and Wildlife Act; Wildlife Policy; and the development of Human Wildlife Conflict Policy, Communal Land Forest Produce Act and the Forest Act.
2020 Target: - Facilitate training of 75 key law enforcement agencies (ZPWMA, ZRP Minerals and Border Control Unit, FC, ZIMRA, EMA, investigators, judiciary, and prosecutors) with necessary trainings and tools to fight IWT and forest crimes
2020 Target: - Involvement of 1000 beneficiaries in awareness campaign targeting IWT, deforestation and climate adaptation/mitigation issues in the project areas
Outcome 2. Improved capacity of PA network and CAMPFIRE Wildlife Conservancies to protect globally significant biodiversity of the mid-lower Zambezi region over a total area of 1,616,900 ha

2020 Target: - Complete process of setting up of 3 CWCs in some districts.

Outcome 1. Increased national capacity for IWT control, and integrated wildlife and woodland management
2020 Target: - Conclude at least 2 drafts of the following acts and policies; Parks and Wildlife Act; Wildlife Policy; and the development of Human Wildlife Conflict Policy, Communal Land Forest Produce Act and the Forest Act.
Although none of the policies have yet been completed, there has been significant progress in terms of preparatory procedures, consultations, reviews and initial analyses, as follows: The process of reviewing wildlife related legislation and institutional frameworks was initiated by conducting nationwide consultations on the Wildlife Policy and the Parks and Wildlife Act. Issues of Human-Wildlife Conflict dominated most consultations. The country requires a Human-Wildlife Conflict Management Policy and this will be included in the Wildlife Policy.
2020 Target: - Facilitate training of 75 key law enforcement agencies (ZPWMA, ZRP Minerals and Border Control Unit, FC, ZIMRA, EMA, investigators, judiciary, and prosecutors) with necessary trainings and tools to fight IWT and forest crimes.
The ZPWMA conducted two trainings for rangers, one on Basic First Aid and the other on management of human-wildlife Conflict Management. The Basic First Aid training was attended by 10 rangers (6 males and 4 females), whilst 25 rangers (2 females and 23 males) attended the human-wildlife conflict management training. The extended lockdown and increasing poverty levels due to the effects of the COVID-19 pandemic negatively impacted law enforcement in the Zambezi Valley during the reporting period. The number of arrests of poachers and other offenders for environment-related crimes increased during the reporting period, and these included underage offenders. The project responded by purchasing drones, boats and increasing rations and fuel for anti-poaching activities.
2020 Target: - Involvement of 1000 beneficiaries in awareness campaign targeting IWT, deforestation and climate adaptation/mitigation issues in the project areas.
The Environmental Management Agency held 32 awareness meetings on veld fire management legislation where 2000 participants attended during the 2020 fire season in the project. In order to increase the awareness levels on dangers of veld fires, EMA also conducted 85 veld fire mobile awareness campaigns in Hurungwe, Mbire and Muzarabani District. The awareness campaigns reached out to at least 10,000 community members. The mobile awareness approach was employed as opposed to community gathering to curb the spread of COVID-19 in the project area. 14 kilometres fireguard was opened up in Muzarabani (8km) and Hurungwe (6km) districts in wards adjacent to the protected areas. Due to the efforts that were made to prepare for the fire season, there was a reduction of area burnt by 4% compared to 2019 fire season in the project area.
Outcome 2. Improved capacity of PA network and CAMPFIRE Wildlife Conservancies to protect globally significant biodiversity of the mid-lower Zambezi region over a total area of 1,616,900 ha
2020 Target: - At least 2 PA management plans are developed.
The process of hiring a consultant to develop the management plans took time. However, the project has provided funds to improve radio communication in the Zambezi Valley through enhanced communication among rangers. The ZPWMA signed a contract with PM Communications on 14 August 2020 for the supply and fixing of the radio equipment for upgrade of the Mid Zambezi Valley Radio System from analogue to digital. Full migration to the digital radio system is expected to be completed during the first third of 2021.
2020 Target: - Complete process of setting up of 3 CWCs in some districts.
The CAMPFIRE Association carried out consultations on the establishment of six Community Trusts in Mbire, Muzarabani and Hurungwe districts, and a total of 845 community members were consulted (645 men and 200 women). Community Trusts will operate in conformity with existing legislation in their interaction with government departments as well as the private sector.
OUTCOME 3 Increased area under sustainable management and increased benefits for local communities from CBWM, SFM and SLM in established CWCs
2020 Target: - Support the establishment of 3 nurseries and drilling of 14 boreholes in 3 CWCs. 78,616 seedlings were produced in 2020. The nursery at Mavhuradonha Wilderness commenced operation in the last third of the year with 14,634 seedlings being produced. Two nurseries have been fenced in the project area and boreholes will be drilled at the nurseries sites The Forestry Commission, ZPWMA and EMA carried out a joint operation to stop illegal charcoal production and firewood sales in Mbire and Muzarabani. 2058 bags of charcoal (packed in 50kg bags) and 13m3 of firewood were confiscated.
2020 Target: - Initiation of at least 6 livelihood enhancement activities through the Small Grants mechanism
The project facilitated the signing of small grant agreements between UNDP and five non-governmental organisations, namely Lower Guruve Development Association (LGDA), Southern Alliance for Indigenous Resources (SAFIRE), Environment Africa, Zim Apiculture Trust and Zambezi Society. To date US$194, 520.00 has been disbursed to support community projects under the small grants component of the project.
2020 TARGET: Project Board and Technical Committees meetings
Two board meetings were conducted in June and December 2020. The project conducted a technical committee in December to review 2020 progress as well discuss the 2020 annual report and 2021 annual work plan. The project steering/board met in December to discuss the 2020 Annual Progress Report and the 2021 Annual Workplan.

Outcome 1. Increased national capacity for IWT control, and integrated wildlife and woodland management 2021 Target: - Conclude at least 2 drafts of the following acts and policies; Parks and Wildlife Act; Wildlife Policy; Human-Wildlife Conflict Management Policy, Communal Land Forest Produce Act ;and the Forest Act. 2021 Target: - Establish one Multi-Agency Wildlife Crime Prevention Unit to ensure strong inter-agency collaboration to fight IWT and forest crimes 2021 Target: - 2,000 beneficiaries are involved in awareness campaign targeting IWT, deforestation and climate adaptation/mitigation issues in the project areas
Outcome 2. Improved capacity of PA network and CAMPFIRE Wildlife Conservancies to protect globally significant biodiversity of the mid-lower Zambezi region over a total area of 1,616,900 ha 2021 Target: - Finalise migration of Zambezi Valley radio communication system from analogue to digital to enhance communication by rangers during patrols. 2021 Target: - Construction of 3 weir dams for wildlife water provision in Hurungwe and Mbire districts 2021 Target: - Construction of 3 pickets in the protected area to enhance anti-poaching activities.
OUTCOME 3 Increased area under sustainable management and increased benefits for local communities from CBWM, SFM and SLM in established CWCs 2021 Target: - Support the establishment of 2 nurseries and drilling of 3 boreholes in 3 CWCs. 2021 Target: - Initiation of at least 2 livelihood enhancement projects through the Small Grants mechanism
OUTCOME 4 Lessons learned by the project through participatory M&E and gender mainstreaming are used nationally and internationally 2021 Target: 2 Lessons learned from the project are shared with national and international conservation programmes, including GWP

description.narrative: Strengthening and optimizing the technical and organizational capacities of the MEWA with respect to water resources and water supply management of the Kingdom
capital of a political entity

sector.narrative: Accelerate structural transformations

description.narrative: Integrated Groundwater Model for the Kingdom and 2 Integrated Hydrological Model for the Kingdom

comment.narrative: An ambitious program for the investigations of its major surface and groundwater resources, for the monitoring of these resources, for the study of hydrological resources (research side), and for the management of the resources (management side).
Combination of existing groundwater models into 3D Model and update and Visualization of 3D groundwater model - GIS

The GIS Map are prepared for the entire succession of aquifers of the Kingdom and Evaluation of the Hydrological process and effects that occur from climate change had started with collection of data from various sources and the study of existing climate models for their adaptation.

Flood Mitigation Master Plan with Consideration of alternative flood mitigation constructions developed and production of a water action plan identifying the main areas for efficiency improvements and potential measures to be taken

Water Model up to 2050 of Demand and Supply for the kingdom was developed and approved. 8 Ground water models were developed and approved; National Water Strategy was updated to be aligned with the Saudi Vision 2030 was completed and approved. Draft for Water law was completed and submitted; New database system was developed and operated. 3 different reports were completed and accepted: Wadi Bisha, Dahran Al Janub and Annual Water Report.
Major Groundwater Studies conducted and models developed

• Demand & Supply Model for (KSA) the Kingdom up to 2050 has been completed and submitted. • Major Groundwater Studies have closed, and models have been developed for: Khuff-Jilh-Minjur; Wajid; Wasia-Biyadh-Aruma; Rub’ Al Khali; Western Coastal Plain National Water Strategy developed and submitted • National Water Law has been drafted and submitted. • Database System: Restoration of various old databases and rescue of data. • Formal Establishment of “National Water Research and Studies Center” • Formal Establishment of “Water Management and Control Center” including the “Hydroinformatics Lab”
Integrated Groundwater and Hydrological Model developed for the Kingdom

description.narrative: 1.1 Número de estrategias, planes y programas de otros sectores relevantes que integran esfuerzos para combatir la violencia feminicida y feminicidios, desarrollados de conformidad con las normas internacionales sobre recursos humanos. 1.2 Número de proyectos de ley nuevos o reforzados sobre el feminicidio y la violencia feminicida, incluidas mujeres, niñas y grupos que enfrentan discriminaciones múltiples e intersectadas, en armonía con las normas internacionales de derechos humanos, que han recibido insumos sustantivos de organizaciones de derechos humanos de la mujer. 1.3 Porcentaje de instituciones nacionales de capacitación para funcionarios/as púbicos que han integrado la igualdad de género y la violencia contra las mujeres, así como estándares internacionales de derechos humanos en sus planes de estudio (Escuela de Capacitación Judicial, Escuela de la FGR, Escuela de la PGR, Academia Nacional de Seguridad Ciudadana). 1.4 Número de mecanismos de coordinación nacional de alto nivel en funcionamiento para atender el feminicidio y la violencia feminicida, que incluye representación de grupos de personas marginalizadas. 1.5 Número de sistemas para evaluar los riesgos y/o alerta temprana diseñado y funcionando. 1.6 Número de operadores que tienen su capacidad mejorada para recopilar datos cuali-cuantitativos sobre prevalencia de feminicidios y violencia contra las mujeres, de conformidad con normas internacionales.

comment.narrative:
1.1 17% increase as compared to the end of Phase I (158 experts in comparison with 135 experts by the end of Phase I have been registered in 15 thematic areas of the database).
1.2 21 applications from 9 countries were received in the framework of the Call for Proposals under Russian Experts on Demand, which was announced in December 2018. 19 applications were approved for funding in 2019. At the same time Implementation of the experts’ assignments under the 3rd round of Russian Experts on Demand programme approved under the Phase I of the KM Project continued in the Phase II. The survey regarding the quality of performance of the Russian experts is envisaged to be conducted in the end-2019 upon completion of majority of assignments.
1.3 The first call for internships was announced in November 2018. 9 Interns were selected to start the internships in February 2019 in Moscow and continue in UNDP country offices and IRH. The survey regarding the level of satisfaction of country offices and returned interns will be conducted in mid-2019 upon completion of internships.
UNV 1. 89% increase (2342 Russian specialists in comparison with 1233 specialists at project’s beginning registered in the UNV roster).
UNV 2. 51% increase (209 volunteers in comparison with 138 volunteers at project’s beginning registered in the Online Volunteer roster).
UNV 3. 90% increase (42 Russian nationals deployed as UN Volunteers in comparison with 22 Russian nationals by the end of Phase I).

1.1 Number of people (disaggregated by gender) registered in database of Russian experts for international development - 20% increase as compared to the baseline. 1.2 Quality of the performance under Russian Experts (disaggregated by gender) on Demand assignments improved - 70%. 1.3 Level of satisfaction of returned secondees and interns with the contribution of the secondment or internship experience to their professional development (disaggregated by gender) - Above expectations of secondees and interns. UNV 1 Number of active profiles of Russian specialists in the UNV pool (gender-disaggregated) - 30% increase. UNV 2 Number of Russian nationals and organizations on the Online Volunteer pool (gender-disaggregated) - 35% increase. Number of experts (by gender) ranked “excellent” or “very good” for technical expertise and quality of reports is to be identified on the Survey results to be summarized early 2020. 1.3. No secondees. The secondment programme was not launched due to lack of legal basis, the reprogramming is a subject for discussion by the PB. UNV 1. Number of active profiles of Russian specialists in UNV roster - 2263 (incl. 1476 women). UNV 2. Number of Russian nationals and organizations on the Online Volunteer pool (gender-disaggregated) - 95 (no gender disaggregated data available). UNV 3. Number of Russian nationals deployed as UN Volunteers (gender-disaggregated) - 50 (76% women) including UN Volunteers under the Russian UNV FF programme.

description.narrative: Vulnerable populations including returning refugees, displaced persons, ex-combatants, women and youth have access to livelihoods opportunities and sustainable employment
seat of a first-order administrative division

sector.narrative: Build resilience to shocks and crisis

description.narrative: 1.Number of gender sensitive Local Development plan developed 2.Number of local government staff who have knowledge on governance 3.Number of Public service facilities functional with equipment 4.Percentage of beneficiaries (50% are women) who become functionally literate 5.Percentage of beneficiaries who have management skills 6.Number of micro-enterprises and associations founded by beneficiaries of the project which have regular income 7. Number of people benefitting from emergency jobs and other livelihoods in crisis or post-crisis settings, disaggregated by sex

Este nuevo Producto tiene como objetivo generar soluciones a desafíos de desarrollo identificados en el marco de los ODS por los consejos de desarrollo locales (municipales) en base a un proceso consultivo participativo.
Una vez identificados y validados por los consejos, se haría un llamado a un concurso público donde el sector privado, la academia y organizaciones de la sociedad civil puedan presentar soluciones a los desafíos que sean viables económicamente y escalables. El PNUD administrará el fondo concursable y las mejores propuestas seleccionadas recibirán financiamiento para implemen

sector.narrative: Accelerate structural transformations

description.narrative: El objetivo principal del proyecto es de fortalecer al Tribunal Superior de Justicia Electoral (TSJE).También fortalecer las dependencias del TSJE para fomentar la participación política de grupos vulnerables y/o excluidos.
capital of a political entity

sector.narrative: Eradicate poverty in all its forms and dimensions

description.narrative: 1. Numero de paises con capacidades fortalecidas para la gobernabilidad y vigilancia d einstituciones del estado de derecho (SP indicador 2.2.3.3.) 2. Número de nuevas tecnologías informáticas o sistemas de gestión que mejoren la eficiencia y transparencia de la gestión electoral de la Justicia Electoral diseñados 3. Grado de satisfacción expresado por participantes de grupos vulnerables o excluidos (jóvenes, mujeres) respecto a sus conocimientos y capacidades para la participación política. Datos disgregados por sexo. Medido por encuesta aplicada con la siguiente escala: 1. Baja; 2. Media; 3. Alta.

comment.narrative: 1. 1 2. 2 3. Debido a que el ciclo de capacitaciones no ha finalizado aún, las encuestas serán aplicadas al cierre de la implementación del proyecto.

1.1) Apply 1 SDG Framework to evaluate the Neixiang County's 13th Five-Year Plan and develop policy recommendation to incorporate the SDGs into Neixiang Country's 14th Five-Year Plan. 1.2) Conduct 1 survey of the social, economic and environmental baselines of Neixiang County, as well as the development and future development trends of the secondary industry. 1.3) Develop 1 monitoring method for Neixiang and conduct annual monitoring for this project. 1.4) Provide 47 capacity building training sessions for government officials in Neixiang County, including trainings on SDGs, development planning, public services, social governance and inclusive finance. 2.1) Carry out 1 baseline survey of social, economic and environment development in the Neixiang County combined with the SDGs Framework, investigate and understand the policy status and data quality of the local key industries combination with the SDGs Framework, investigate and understand the policy status and data quality of the local key industries. 2.2) Prepare 1 development guideline based on the SDGs Framework and the assessment of the implementation of Neixiang County’s 13th Five-Year Plan; organize meetings and seminars of relevant industries and compile a social, economic and environmental development planning roadmap for Neixiang County. 2.3) Prepare 1 report on inclusive development and inclusive finance development in Neixiang County and formulate incentive policies and measures. 2.4) Select 2 key industry as sustainable development planning pilot according to the social, economic and environmental development planning roadmap. 3.1) Carry out 1 need assessment for capacity building activities and adopt a systematic approach to assess the status and development needs of relevant departments when implementing the SDGs, especially for those department with planning functions in the Neixiang Principle Government. 3.2) Conduct 1 case study of best practices for sustainable development in the domestic counties. 3.3) Conduct 1 case study of best practices for sustainable development in foreign counties or similar districts. 3.4) Develop 5 methodologies for monitoring sustainable development target indicators and monitor the implementation of SDGs in Neixiang County. 4.1) 1 baseline surveys, conduct baseline surveys in demonstration areas, including farmer upgrade surveys; community service status surveys; community service needs surveys. 4.2) Increase 1 collective assets and increase income of collective asset by supporting the preparation and implementation of village collective economic development demonstration plan, through the rational use of demonstration village resources, in particular, the rational use of homesteads. 4.3) Improve 1 community service functions, achieve a dynamic integration of rural pension, rural minimum living standard security system and dynamic integration services to demonstrate ageing services at the village level. 4.4) Support the preparation and implementation of 1 village collective economic development demonstration plan, by effectively using the villages’ resource in demonstration area, especially have a better use of the homesteads, increase collective assets, and increase collective asset income. 5.1) Plan 1 demonstration primary schools based on local geographical conditions and population distribution. 5.2) Provide 7 public services such as school bus services to facilitate rural left-behind children to enter school. 5.3) Improve the quality of 35 rural school teachers and enhance the attractiveness of rural teachers. description.narrative:
O. 1 - Number of municipal needs assessments conducted - Number of light infrastructure rehabilitated - Number of equipment provided - Number of critical businesses rehabilitated
O. 2 - Number of capacity assessments - Number of technical experts deployed - Number of local authorities with increased capacity O. 3 - Number of local assessments conducted - Number of civic engagement campaigns - Number of youth and women engaged - Number of municipalities trained and engaged in conflict resolution efforts

comment.narrative:
Output 1: Light infrastructure destroyed by conflict rehabilitated and recovery of critical businesses supported Key infrastructure destroyed in the intensified conflict since mid-2014 disrupting the regular functioning of hospitals, schools, roads, electricity networks, power grids, police stations, and water facilities - Local businesses (MSMEs) impacted by the crisis. - Lack of viable economic opportunities for jobs and income generation for youth, including vulnerable groups (IDPs, returnees, and migrants).
Output 2: Immediate capacity boost to municipalities provided - Municipalities lack human resource and financial capacity to effective function in their role as local authorities. - Traditional and weak bureaucratic systems in local institutions (municipalities and executive bodies) - Current partnership building between local actors is ad hoc, externally driven, unstructured and reactive. - Inadequate levels of financial transparency. - Limited engagement with civil society and media. - Marked decrease in access to and quality of basic services in certain areas and even more so for the 700,000 persons of concern (IDPs, refugees, migrants).
Output 3: Local conflict analysis, facilitation and mediation capacity strengthened - Role of municipalities in mediation and conflict resolution remains ad hoc. - Traditional leaders and structures play an important role in local mediation and conflict mitigation, but these efforts mainly act as mitigation of escalation following an incident, rather than as an effective peacebuilding mechanism. - Existing conflict management and dialogue efforts at local level are not sufficiently visible, remain ad hoc and reactive rather than preventative. - Level of violent criminality and threats against private property increasing across the country. - Protective system for women against violence is weak, due to institutional and cultural barriers.

title.narrative: Women in Peace Bldg& Conf Res

description.narrative: The Women in Peace (WiP) project is a short-term-one-year project aimed at responding to the recurring and emerging conflicts in Oromia and Somali regions of Ethiopia. In 2020 it is also repurposed to respond to impacts of COVID 19 on women.
capital of a political entity

sector.narrative: Build resilience to shocks and crisis

description.narrative: 1. No of Regional Women Council members with enhanced awareness on the role of women in peace and conflict resolution in Oromia and Somali regions

comment.narrative: 1. None for a specific peace building and conflict resolution capacity 2. No Data -for the assessment documents on the role of women in peace building 3. No COVID 19 response plan to support women
1. Enhanced Capacity of 73 women leaders on peace building and conflict resolution

1. 148 women leaders from CSOs(50), Regional Councils OF Oromia, Somali and SNNPR(46) , House of Federation (10), House of People's Representative(35), Ministry of Peace (5) and Ministry of Women Children and Youth(2) were trained to enhance their knowledge on the role of women in conflict resolution and peace building.

As a result of the strategies employed by WiP project, the following results has been realized in the year 2020:- - An assessment report on the role of women in peace and reconciliation in Oromia and Somali Regions was produced to inform peacebuilding programming by addressing the challenges of evidence on the role of women in peace and security in those targeted regions. - As part of the continuing efforts to building the capacity of women for peacebuilding, consecutive trainings on Conflict Prevention, Management, and Mediation Skills were provided for 424 women in addition to the 148 women who were trained in 2019. These women were from Ministry of Women, Children and Youth, Oromia Regional State Councils local CSOs, and women peace ambassadors and traditional mediators from the 9 regional states. - Following the spread of COVID 19 Pandemic in Ethiopia , the project also repurposed and extended with additional 6 month from June - December 2020. The aim was to address the emerging unique challenges of women both as victims of the pandemic and as agents for change in the context of peacebuilding and conflict resolution. Accordingly, 4641 Internally Displaced People (IDPs) were reached by providing with Personal Protective Equipment (PPE). - As part of the efforts to promoting the role of women in peace, three consecutive media panel discussions were conducted by engaging representatives of public and religious institutions, CSOs, and media houses. The panel discussions were watched by 1191 YouTube viewers in addition to the audience reached during the transmission of the panel on the public TV called Walta. Two infographic Amharic and English video messages were also produced to back the public awareness effort on the Media. These videos promote the role of women as agents of peace by highlighting their practical role in different traditional settings in Ethiopia.

- Subnational authorities have enhanced capacities to engage in holistic, area-based planning and consider different scenarios that respond to the needs of the host, refugee, and internally displaced persons (IDP) populations - Service delivery is increasingly responsive and generates more significant social stability outcomes based on the needs of the host, refugee, and IDP populations - Subnational authorities are empowered to facilitate local economic development (LED) and have better access to municipal investment that benefits the extension of safe public services and economic opportunities for the host, refugee, and IDP populations

In support of outcome 1: Subnational authorities have enhanced capacities to engage in holistic, area-based planning and consider different scenarios that respond to the needs of the host, refugee, and internally displaced persons (IDP) populations, in 2020, the Project started its engagement on capacity development of subnational authorities. Specific results are as follows:  The assessment of the DGLAC was initiated  Mediation units were established at UoM level and training of unit members was initiated  An internal social stability strategy was developed  The Bourj Hamoud Municipal hotline was established  A detailed approach for municipal finance was finalized and a service provider to conduct the planned Municipal Finance Assessments was contracted  Capacity development and training on raising revenues and financial management was initiated
In support of outcome 2: Service delivery is increasingly responsive and generates more significant social stability outcomes based on the needs of the host, refugee, and IDP populations, in 2020, the Project initiated its engagement on service delivery. Specific results are as follows:  The assessment of the Regional Technical Offices (RTOs) was completed  RTOs in Tyre and Al Fayaha’a were supported with grants  Recruitment of RTO staff for the Bourj Hammoud Municipality and refurbishment of the RTO office for the Bourj Hammoud Municipality was initiated
In support of outcome 3. Subnational authorities are empowered to facilitate local economic development (LED) and have better access to municipal investment that benefits the extension of safe public services and economic opportunities for the host, refugee, and IDP populations, in 2020, specific results are as follows:  The Project finalized a detailed concept note for its LED component  The Project launched a procurement process for the planned LED assessments  The Project launched the call for concept notes for basic service and LED projects for municipalities and UoMs and contracted a service provider to support municipalities and UoMs in this process through mentoring and coaching.
In addition to the above, the Project also further strengthened its M&E and communications work. In terms of M&E, in 2020, the project finalized its M&E framework, the baseline concept note in order to integrate the baseline in the project planned assessments, in addition to the M&E tools of the Social Stability component. In terms of communications and visibility, in 2020 the Project formally launched its activities in the three partner UoMs through a series of events. See section VIII Communication and Visibility for more information.
- Recruit project staff - Launch the project - Launch the Capacity Assessment and receive the first draft. - Establish offices in the Ministry premises

One of the main achievements during this year has been the establishment of the project with regards to buying in the support of the central Government, as well as engaging in discussions with government representatives in the areas where the project is being implemented. The full team was recruited, and all members are on board.
With the arrival of the CTA, the project team conducted a series of meetings to establish a common vision and strategy to project implementation. This resulted in a series of short papers on issues such as project principles, partnerships, scaling, sustainability and M&E. The procurement process was completed and a consultancy firm, KDC, recruited to carry out a capacity assessment of the local authorities in the targeted areas, municipalities, and unions of municipalities of Al Fayhaa, Metn Chemali, and Tyre. The main goal of the multi-thematic capacity/functional assessment is to identify the strengths, gaps, potential risks and vulnerabilities to corruption, opportunities for inclusiveness, and challenges existing within municipalities and UoMs on the human resources and the internal and external processes levels. However, due to the emerging situation in Lebanon, the Capacity Assessment was cancelled, and discussions are taking place with the EU and the Ministry of Interior and Municipalities to replace this activity.
Moreover, in the context of developing mechanisms for social stability, a Terms of Reference was developed, and procurement process initiated for the development of capacity of the three targeted unions on mediation skills. The proposed initiative will build on the already existing work of UNDP and UN Habitat with regards to Host Communities and Urban populations. However, the overarching intent will be to go one step further and develop capacity, particularly at the sub national level, that will result in Unions of Municipalities and Municipalities being better able to manage the impact of the crisis. The intention is to leverage the investments in a manner that enables systems strengthening and results in stronger, more capable and accountable sub national structures. This is in essence the transformative agenda of the Resilience approach where funding targeting a crisis contributes to longer term change.
The proposed intervention is focused on systems strengthening aiming to improve local level dispute resolution and community security. In this regard, this capacity building initiative will lead to promoting inter-community dialogue and building social cooperation as achievable results contributing to social cohesion in the targeted areas.
Furthermore, Office space for the team has been ensured at the DGM and MoIM. UNDP and UN-Habitat finalized office rehabilitation and offices project staff moved to new sites and the procurement process of office furniture, IT equipment, and cars were finalized.

description.narrative: 1.1 (cumulative) # of countries/territory implementing models of integrated service delivery for disadvantaged groups , with a specific focus on the youth NEET and vulnerable women; 1.2 (cumulative) # of trained PES, CSW, CSO practitioners to serve marginalized clients

comment.narrative: 1.1. None of the WB6 implements integrated service delivery in a systematic manner 1.2. 54 countries have some form of legal document envisioning integrated service delivery 1.3. 1.3 (cumulative) # of trained PES, CSW, CSO practitioners to serve marginalized clients

1.1. National roadmaps for integrated case management are being implemented in 2 countries and territory Kosovo* - Feasibility study for EMIS-SAS linkages and Active Inclusion Integration Platform completed. Serbia - In-depth analysis of the barriers for ‘hard to employ’ FSAB and ALMM users was completed, legal assessment, reform recommendations, manual for staff and users and factsheet were drafted. Database integration between PES-CSW started. Kosovo* - Active Inclusion Integration Platform is under construction. Co-supporting the creation of Kosovo Job Portal web application. Montenegro - Software for automatic data exchange between Employment Agency’s and SWIS is developed and currently being tested. 1.2.Capacity development for case managers went online in Serbia illustrating an example for potential replication.

1.1. The revitalized Cantonal Council for Labour Market Reform and Human Resource Development in Canton Sarajevo (BiH) envisages an overhaul of ALMPs through integrated service delivery for marginalized individuals including through canton-level regulations for interinstitutional collaboration and service-design. The territorial audit is completed and the report is due February 2020. In Albania, post-earthquake recovery delayed the rollout of the ICM institutionalization process in 3 municipalities – as the municipal level remain the building block for public employment and social welfare service provision. 1.2. The front-runners in achieving interinstitutional collaboration are Montenegro and North Macedonia followed by Serbia and Kosovo*. In Montenegro the database integration between Employment Agency and SWIS is in its final stage due March 2020. In North Macedonia, UNICEF-led ICM installation serves as a solid basis for profiling and individual employment planning. In Serbia, the finalization of the study for “developing instruments to improve the employability assessment system within PES” in the first half of 2020 will pave the way for introducing individual employment planning by case counselors. In Kosovo*, Active Inclusion Integration Platform (AIIP) which will link the Ministry of Labour and Social Welfare with Employment Agency of Kosovo will serve as institutional basis for profiling practice. 1.3. In the reporting period, UNDP COs consulted with and identified potential trainers and drafted the training curriculum. In Montenegro the preparations for a workshop with PES and CSW staff are ongoing and the workshop is scheduled for April/May 2020 following the full operationalization of the integrated IT system. In North Macedonia a Concept Note on a Training Center for case counselors has been initiated in consultation with the government counterparts – in synergy with UNICEF-led activities aiming to build capacities of PES and CSW staff in case management. In Serbia, trainings are scheduled for the second quarter of 2020 for PES staff in profiling and risk assessment in accordance with the model/methodology for profiling, for which PES already secured external support. Potential trainers were iden-tified and training programmes were drafted.

1.1. PES-CSW in WB6 3 WB countries/territory enact protocols for collaboration at central/local level. 1.2. At least 4 countries/territory have improved the profiling and individual planning of employment and social protection needs. 1.3. A cadre of 300 practitioners have knowledge and competences to apply holistic approaches to employment and social protection
